Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: Synchronization of the Polar Regions and the Origin of the Bipolar Seesaw
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research supports the examination of the coupling and synchronization of polar climate oscillations. The researcher postulates that each polar region behaves as a self-sustained relaxation oscillator with its own natural frequency and nonlinear feedbacks influencing each other through dissipative coupling proportional to the temperature and heat storage gradients between North and South Atlantic Ocean and atmosphere. The researcher will examine polar synchronization and the possible connection to Heinrich events.

The broader impacts of the research include the support of a doctoral student and the participation of undergraduate students in the research project

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synchronization is a widespread phenomenon in nonlinear, physical, chemical and biological systems. It describes the phenomena whereby two or more weakly interacting, nonlinear oscillators adjust their natural frequencies until they lock in phase and frequency. This behavior has been observed in biological, chemical and electronic systems, including neurons, fireflies, and computers, but has not been widely studied in climate. This NSF-funded project involves the study of several cases of synchronized climatic systems in different time scales. A first important finding reveals the global climate’s gradual synchronization to the Earth’s 413kyr orbital eccentricity band, which we show starts at the Mid-Pleistocene transition (~1Ma) with the phase lock between the solar forcing and the climate response (Rial et al. 2013). A second major example of stable synchronization in the climate system is the continuous, 90 degree phase lock of the polar climate signals for the available methane-matched record (~90ky) (Rial 2012; Oh et al. 2014). These results resolve the controversy on the phase difference between the polar climates, and therefore what the hemispheric seesaw is. A third important product of our research group has been the retrieval, by a careful application of spectral deconvolution, of the transfer function that connects the two Polar Regions and that is likely responsible for keeping them synchronized (Reischmann et al. 2016a). This transfer function is nearly monochromatic, and suggests that the signal is predominately communicated north to south with a period of 1.6kyrs. This narrows down possible mechanisms of polar connection, and is further investigated via a collection of intermediate proxy datasets and a set of more contemporary, synchronized, sea surface temperature dipoles (Reischmann et al. 2016b). While the former fails to show any strong indication of the nature of the polar signal due in part to the overwhelming uncertainties present on the centennial and millennial scales, the latter demonstrates a large set of synchronized climate oscillations exist, communicate in a variety of networks, and have a direct connection to larger climate patterns (in this case, precipitation anomalies). Our new methods of climate time series analysis uncovers evidence of 16 stable, synchronized sea surface temperature dipoles, and provides a detailed sediment core database with explanations of age model limitations for future investigation (Reischmann et al. 2016b).

In summary, these results represent a clear advance in our understanding of global climate dynamics at a variety of time scales, from the long term synchronization with the 400ky eccentricity forcing to the 100yr records of ocean temperature.
